reviewText: ..and yeah, I know this might just be one of my own personal pet peeves but I friggin HATE toilet humour. Yaknow, some people like it, OK, I get that, but why does it seem like post 1995 no one can seem to accomplish making a kids show/movie without bathroom jokes?Is that seriously what we've come to, is that really the only way people think comedy can be accomplished? I mean the 3 stooges still delight people generation after generation without it. I'm only 38 so not sure if I'm in that "old prude" category, but geez, it seems like Mike Judge's "Idiocracy" is happening right before my eyes.

reviewText: I got this DVD to keep my son busy during a very long car ride. Let's just say, it's a miracle. My son was hypnotized by this cartoon and it made our trip seem like a breeze. So glad I bought it.

reviewText: I never expected this show to be as good as it was.  Thinking it was only a kids show I easily dismissed it.  Watching these shows on video, without those pesky commercials, I have to say this is a great cartoon for all ages.  I never thought I'd see all my old cartoon favorites from my Marvel generation.  It was terrific to see Captain America, Iron Man and all the Avengers,Defenders and Dr. Strange too! All the Marvel heroes and villians you can think of in one show that doesn't take itself too seriously.  I'd reccomend this show to anyone who loves the genre of super heroes.
summary: Great Show that uses 40 years of Marvel History!!

reviewText: First, let me say that I am reviewing the show, not the DVD. That given, is this a good show?Personally, I don't think so.The first thing I really do not like about this show is that without (one hopes) actually meaning to be, it is unbelievably sexist. It's not just that all the members of the core group of superheroes are male. It's that all - yes, all - of the female characters who do appear on the show invariably fit into one of the following three stereotypes:1. Nagging, screeching shrew. Case in point: Ms. Marvel, who's always concerned that the real heroes of the show are messing up her nice clean house... uh... I mean, headquarters.2. Hot guest star love interest. Case in point: the Black Widow. Hubba Hubba.3. Baddies. They're bad. Geddit? In a one-dimensional show such as this one, there's really not much more to say.The Marvel Universe is a rich and complex one, filled with limitless opportunities to find female characters who can be - and indeed, are - so much more than these crude, chauvinist stereotypes.Since first posting this review I have received a lot of flak from the fans of this show, including some comments claiming that there are female characters who are exceptions to this rule. It's true, there are: but only if you count the female characters who appear as little more than background wallpaper. The kind of characters who appear in one, or at most two episodes, and get to speak anywhere between zero and four lines before disappearing entirely, never to be heard from again. At least, not until the second season, which is, believe it or not, actually a little bit better on this front. I think at some point the writers did wake up to themselves and what they were doing here.But... back to season one.Even though I'm writing this review from the perspective of a grown-up animation fan, if I did have kids of my own I would have misgivings about raising them on such material. I'm laissez-faire enough that if I did find myself in the position of having children who wanted to see this show, I don't think I'd actually stop them. But I would at least sit down and discuss with them the view of women implicit in what they were watching.The second thing that I'm unhappy about is that even rampant sexism aside, there's still not much here to appeal to adult audiences.The superhero genre, so completely escapist, so profoundly at odds with all that we laughingly refer to as reality, has always been ripe for parody. This show is pure parody and never tries to pretend otherwise. Well, fair enough. There have been some magnificent superhero parodies over the years. The Adam West Batman was probably the most famous example: a show that cleverly appealed to adults and children alike by mercilessly lampooning its own absurdity. The result was an awesome, glorious, fabulous show. Parody at its most over the top extreme. A wondrously idiotic frolic through psychedelic lunacy.The Superhero Squad Show doesn't live up to that legacy. I know that virtually all cartoons are at least nominally children's shows - here in the west, anyway. But the fact is there are many adults who watch and love them. The Superhero Squad Show just doesn't have what it takes to appeal on that adult level. Rather than a clever spoof with a knowing wink to the audience, 99% of the time all we get are one dimensional... well... cartoon characters. And I don't mean that in a good way. The multiple layers of meaning that it takes to produce a really good parody just aren't there.To the folks who are actually making this show, I'd say simply this: If you want to produce parody, fine. Produce parody. Parody can be great. Parody can be intelligent. Parody can even be devastatingly insightful. All the things that this show is not.But speaking finally to the creators as what they most fundamentally are - the inheritors of a glorious, magnificent, and incredibly diverse superheroic cosmology..?Parody or not, you can do better than this.Theo.
summary: An astonishingly sexist show with not much to appeal to adult audiences
